author: Wilhelm Arcturus
excerpt: Picking up from last time, once I hit the quest level step in the middle of Angmar, I headed off to Forochel to continue my journey towards Mordor. Into the land of snow… or another land of …
text: Picking up from last time, once I hit the quest level step in the middle of Angmar, I headed off to Forochel to continue my journey towards Mordor.  Into the land of snow… or another land of snow, since the Misty Mountains are also a snow zone. Snowy times in Forochel I have gone on about the negative side of the zone before.  While I am not a huge fan of snow zones… just one would have been fine… what really makes Forochel a chore is its sheer size.  In a past post I charted out the time to ride between stable masters using their horses. Your direct travel options in Forochel I compared this with the Lone Lands where the stable master ride between the Forsaken Inn and Ost Guruth, nearly the full length of the zone, is about four minutes total.  And there is swift travel option, which skips most of the ride.  Out in Forochel some of the routes have no swift travel, and those that do require you to get to known status with the locals… and you don’t start out as acquaintance but as a total stranger. Fortunately, as I will no doubt repeat a few dozen times more along this venture, I am not here to be a completionist the way I was back in that 2019 post I linked.  I was free to pick and choose what I wanted to do.  So I made it to level 48 without ever bothering with Kuru-leiri, saving myself all the time the ride there takes.  There are a pile of good, meaty (some literally) quests out there so I was satisfied.  I was also happy a hunter can setup a camp fire to take  the chill effect of the zone off of me. Campfire in the tundra Having gotten there I started to unwind another quest chain that sent me back to Esteldin then Rivendell and finally to Eregion.  Tip for travelers… opt for the fast travel from Rivendell to Eregion.  You would think I would have learned after Forochel, but no.  I went the long way and, even though the ride wrapped up at least one exploration deed, I could have gone and had dinner while waiting for that ride to end. That dropped me in Gwingris, in the northwest of the zone, but I wanted to be at Echad Dunann, in the southeast of the zone.  Another mithril coin spent… swift travel this time… so I could get to where the legendary item quest would begin. Map of Eregion – Old Version I gather that you can now start on that at any time after level 45, but that it can be a bit dicey until you’re a couple more levels in.  At 48 I felt like it was time to go.  The quest chain sends you into the Walls of Moria mini-zone where you fetch and carry for the dwarves who are trying to get back into Moria after the fellowship stirred up the monster in the lake. honestly, it doesn’t seem like that much debris… Once again, I have been through this quest chain in detail in another post, at least the start of it.  You help the dwarves by bringing them lunch, carrying their stuff around, and killing wolves and crows, then they make you break the last couple of rocks before the door… because what the hell? This is another one of those zones where you are better off not thinking too hard on what is going on in the books about now.  Like… isn’t a war brewing?  Haven’t representatives of Sauron been to the dwarves offering up the rings of old?  Do you have the resources to both fight Mordor AND start on a giant public works project in Moria?  This question nags as you make your way through the next expansion. Anyway, eventually the dwarf NPCs that have been obsessively throwing stones in the lake wake up the monster and you can’t fight it because your bow is not ‘leet, so you have to go back and get a ‘leet weapon… or legendary weapon… or whatever. In the before times… before the revised legendary items mechanics… you got a class appropriate purple item and were on your way. Hundi’s discount legendaries… 2019 version Now you get… a yellow item. Drive a Hundi Legendary The bow is at least an upgrade.  I seem to recall that wasn’t always the case right away. The old bow vs. the new Hundi then sends you to Rivedell with the instructions not to freaking reforge your weapon until you are specifically told to by Dithalion. Do NOT Reforge Yet You get some follow on quests in Rivendell that all tell you to NOT reforge yet, then finally sends you on a story mission to Moria of the past where you play one of the dwarves in the giant halls of Durin VI, which are so annoyingly large that they give you a fast run skill because it is literally 200m from where you start to Durin VI, who is the first NPC you need to speak with. Running to get to Durin Also, you are playing another class which has none of the skills I have spent the last 47 levels using AND it resets all your UI to the defaults AND that includes your chat filters so my initial experience of the instance is now suddenly I am being spammed by world chat garbage in a tiny window in the lower right corner of my screen.  Not cool SSG, not cool at all. The whole thing is to fill in some backstory about WHY the dwarves got kicked out of Moria… stuff that gets explained in the book along the way with the fellowship, but maybe you haven’t read the book, seen the movies, or experienced the memes, so SSG decided you needed to BE THERE and see it all in some crazy  yet succinct way. So you, Durin VI, his son, and delegation of elves all just happen to be there to knock down one last well… and true to the lazy NPC theme, you have to go to that final bit of wall to knock it down.  Seriously, the king and an honored delegation from the elves, down in the mines to play diggy hole. Let’s go dig some holes! So you run over, break through a pretty flimsy rock wall and, hey presto, there is a giant balrog on the other side in a giant chamber and he is ready to kill everybody dead and you all run away… or mostly all, Durin does at least stay behind to fight… and the elves, having seen this, start in on recriminations even as the balrog is standing right there ready to attack. I will grant that is a pretty cool looking balrog And then we all ran some more then escaped and then the event is over and you get handed a SECOND legendary item, which is good because most classes have two things going on… sword and board for your guardians, something in each hand for champions, and a bow with a sword backup for hunters… and then that is it. Now, I will admit that I might have missed it, but I cannot recall Dithalion finally giving me the green light to reforge my stuffs which, given all the nearly unreadable tiny red text you would think might earn at least some tiny unreadable green text saying to go forth and reforge.  Again, all the quest text is tiny and unreadable and not scalable, so I could have missed it. But I had started reading the LOTRO Wiki entry on legendary items because the game seemed intent on doing a bad job of explaining things.  But even after reading that, I still don’t undstand what is really required or going on, with the game just not helping all that much.  I did grasp the whole “you need to reforge at selected levels now” and did, in fact, go reforge both items.  But actually upgrading the legendary items… that was not well explained. For example, I went to the menu to find the good old Legendary Items option and selected it. This is here, on the menu, with all the stuff And that brings up the old legendary item window which… so far as I can tell… does nothing. The Window, It Does Nothing Now, in mousing over the items I have equipped I could see that they had slots and what not, but it wasn’t obvious how to… you know… bring up the freaking window to edit them.  Then, because I was just mousing over everything I did eventually find a spot on my character panel where you drag your legendary item to then open up the window to work with it. Drag item here to edit Fine.  It is one of those things that once you know it is there it is okay.  But it is also a moment of “here is a brand new UI convention that we’re just going to assume you’ll know and understand at a glace” that, like the reforging bit, might have been covered in some tiny quest text, but probably should have been in flashed on the screen or given its own instruction window. [And yes, I did eventually find the tiny little control on the bottom of the quest window to scale up the text size.  But still, why put the control in that already very busy window instead of the config area that scales other things?  Why can’t the window, which has plenty of tiny text, scale up like other windows?  Also, why can’t I resize that window horizontally?  And why does it forget my setting every time I exit the game?  All things to go into in another post.] In the end I got there, but it feels like the the sort of instructions you get from somebody who knows how to do something so they assume a lot of knowledge you don’t have. That done, I went back to Echad Dunann, went into the instance and finished up the dance with the monster in the lake, and ended up in the first room of Moria.  I grabbed the stable master update, then left. On the one hand, I don’t need to be a completionist, so I could have left Eregion behind.  On the other hand, Moria has a way of sapping ones will to play at times so I figured I should just wrap up at least the low hanging fruit quests there and get a couple levels up on things. Damn littering hobbits Also, I wanted to try and figure out the legendary item thing on some more familiar ground I suppose… not that the game is good at giving hints.  I am probably going to have to find a guide to them somewhere better than the wiki entry, which more like an ingredients list than a “how to” guide to the mechanics. All of the above had gotten me pretty deep into level 49, so level 50 came quickly enough. Celebrating a milestone the LOTRO way! I will probably hang out there until 52 before moving forward. So there we go.  Since the launch of the Glamdring server one month ago I have made it to Moria and can go in the dark hole any time I am ready.
html:
Picking up from last time, once I hit the quest level step in the middle of Angmar, I headed off to Forochel to continue my journey towards Mordor.  Into the land of snow… or another land of snow, since the Misty Mountains are also a snow zone.

Snowy times in Forochel

I have gone on about the negative side of the zone before.  While I am not a huge fan of snow zones… just one would have been fine… what really makes Forochel a chore is its sheer size.  In a past post I charted out the time to ride between stable masters using their horses.

Your direct travel options in Forochel

I compared this with the Lone Lands where the stable master ride between the Forsaken Inn and Ost Guruth, nearly the full length of the zone, is about four minutes total.  And there is swift travel option, which skips most of the ride.  Out in Forochel some of the routes have no swift travel, and those that do require you to get to known status with the locals… and you don’t start out as acquaintance but as a total stranger.

Fortunately, as I will no doubt repeat a few dozen times more along this venture, I am not here to be a completionist the way I was back in that 2019 post I linked.  I was free to pick and choose what I wanted to do.  So I made it to level 48 without ever bothering with Kuru-leiri, saving myself all the time the ride there takes.  There are a pile of good, meaty (some literally) quests out there so I was satisfied.  I was also happy a hunter can setup a camp fire to take  the chill effect of the zone off of me.

Campfire in the tundra

Having gotten there I started to unwind another quest chain that sent me back to Esteldin then Rivendell and finally to Eregion.  Tip for travelers… opt for the fast travel from Rivendell to Eregion.  You would think I would have learned after Forochel, but no.  I went the long way and, even though the ride wrapped up at least one exploration deed, I could have gone and had dinner while waiting for that ride to end.

That dropped me in Gwingris, in the northwest of the zone, but I wanted to be at Echad Dunann, in the southeast of the zone.  Another mithril coin spent… swift travel this time… so I could get to where the legendary item quest would begin.

Map of Eregion – Old Version

I gather that you can now start on that at any time after level 45, but that it can be a bit dicey until you’re a couple more levels in.  At 48 I felt like it was time to go.  The quest chain sends you into the Walls of Moria mini-zone where you fetch and carry for the dwarves who are trying to get back into Moria after the fellowship stirred up the monster in the lake.

honestly, it doesn’t seem like that much debris…

Once again, I have been through this quest chain in detail in another post, at least the start of it.  You help the dwarves by bringing them lunch, carrying their stuff around, and killing wolves and crows, then they make you break the last couple of rocks before the door… because what the hell?

This is another one of those zones where you are better off not thinking too hard on what is going on in the books about now.  Like… isn’t a war brewing?  Haven’t representatives of Sauron been to the dwarves offering up the rings of old?  Do you have the resources to both fight Mordor AND start on a giant public works project in Moria?  This question nags as you make your way through the next expansion.

Anyway, eventually the dwarf NPCs that have been obsessively throwing stones in the lake wake up the monster and you can’t fight it because your bow is not ‘leet, so you have to go back and get a ‘leet weapon… or legendary weapon… or whatever.

In the before times… before the revised legendary items mechanics… you got a class appropriate purple item and were on your way.

Hundi’s discount legendaries… 2019 version

Now you get… a yellow item.

Drive a Hundi Legendary

The bow is at least an upgrade.  I seem to recall that wasn’t always the case right away.

The old bow vs. the new

Hundi then sends you to Rivedell with the instructions not to freaking reforge your weapon until you are specifically told to by Dithalion.

Do NOT Reforge Yet

You get some follow on quests in Rivendell that all tell you to NOT reforge yet, then finally sends you on a story mission to Moria of the past where you play one of the dwarves in the giant halls of Durin VI, which are so annoyingly large that they give you a fast run skill because it is literally 200m from where you start to Durin VI, who is the first NPC you need to speak with.

Running to get to Durin

Also, you are playing another class which has none of the skills I have spent the last 47 levels using AND it resets all your UI to the defaults AND that includes your chat filters so my initial experience of the instance is now suddenly I am being spammed by world chat garbage in a tiny window in the lower right corner of my screen.  Not cool SSG, not cool at all.

The whole thing is to fill in some backstory about WHY the dwarves got kicked out of Moria… stuff that gets explained in the book along the way with the fellowship, but maybe you haven’t read the book, seen the movies, or experienced the memes, so SSG decided you needed to BE THERE and see it all in some crazy  yet succinct way.

So you, Durin VI, his son, and delegation of elves all just happen to be there to knock down one last well… and true to the lazy NPC theme, you have to go to that final bit of wall to knock it down.  Seriously, the king and an honored delegation from the elves, down in the mines to play diggy hole.

Let’s go dig some holes!

So you run over, break through a pretty flimsy rock wall and, hey presto, there is a giant balrog on the other side in a giant chamber and he is ready to kill everybody dead and you all run away… or mostly all, Durin does at least stay behind to fight… and the elves, having seen this, start in on recriminations even as the balrog is standing right there ready to attack.

I will grant that is a pretty cool looking balrog

And then we all ran some more then escaped and then the event is over and you get handed a SECOND legendary item, which is good because most classes have two things going on… sword and board for your guardians, something in each hand for champions, and a bow with a sword backup for hunters… and then that is it.

Now, I will admit that I might have missed it, but I cannot recall Dithalion finally giving me the green light to reforge my stuffs which, given all the nearly unreadable tiny red text you would think might earn at least some tiny unreadable green text saying to go forth and reforge.  Again, all the quest text is tiny and unreadable and not scalable, so I could have missed it.

But I had started reading the LOTRO Wiki entry on legendary items because the game seemed intent on doing a bad job of explaining things.  But even after reading that, I still don’t undstand what is really required or going on, with the game just not helping all that much.  I did grasp the whole “you need to reforge at selected levels now” and did, in fact, go reforge both items.  But actually upgrading the legendary items… that was not well explained.

For example, I went to the menu to find the good old Legendary Items option and selected it.

This is here, on the menu, with all the stuff

And that brings up the old legendary item window which… so far as I can tell… does nothing.

The Window, It Does Nothing

Now, in mousing over the items I have equipped I could see that they had slots and what not, but it wasn’t obvious how to… you know… bring up the freaking window to edit them.  Then, because I was just mousing over everything I did eventually find a spot on my character panel where you drag your legendary item to then open up the window to work with it.

Drag item here to edit

Fine.  It is one of those things that once you know it is there it is okay.  But it is also a moment of “here is a brand new UI convention that we’re just going to assume you’ll know and understand at a glace” that, like the reforging bit, might have been covered in some tiny quest text, but probably should have been in flashed on the screen or given its own instruction window.

[And yes, I did eventually find the tiny little control on the bottom of the quest window to scale up the text size.  But still, why put the control in that already very busy window instead of the config area that scales other things?  Why can’t the window, which has plenty of tiny text, scale up like other windows?  Also, why can’t I resize that window horizontally?  And why does it forget my setting every time I exit the game?  All things to go into in another post.]

In the end I got there, but it feels like the the sort of instructions you get from somebody who knows how to do something so they assume a lot of knowledge you don’t have.

That done, I went back to Echad Dunann, went into the instance and finished up the dance with the monster in the lake, and ended up in the first room of Moria.  I grabbed the stable master update, then left.

On the one hand, I don’t need to be a completionist, so I could have left Eregion behind.  On the other hand, Moria has a way of sapping ones will to play at times so I figured I should just wrap up at least the low hanging fruit quests there and get a couple levels up on things.

Damn littering hobbits

Also, I wanted to try and figure out the legendary item thing on some more familiar ground I suppose… not that the game is good at giving hints.  I am probably going to have to find a guide to them somewhere better than the wiki entry, which more like an ingredients list than a “how to” guide to the mechanics.

All of the above had gotten me pretty deep into level 49, so level 50 came quickly enough.

Celebrating a milestone the LOTRO way!

I will probably hang out there until 52 before moving forward.

So there we go.  Since the launch of the Glamdring server one month ago I have made it to Moria and can go in the dark hole any time I am ready.
